clinical_study.brief_title: Preoperative Intravenous Iron Therapy in Patients With Gastric Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Preoperative Intravenous Iron Therapy in Patients With Gastric Cancer

brief_summary.textblock: The main objective of this investigator initiated study is to study if preoperative intravenous iron is effective in reducing need for allogenic blood transfusion in patients with gastric cancer who will undergo a standardized gastrectomy including both total and subtotal gastrectomies. The hypothesis is that intravenous iron reduces the need for perioperative blood transfusions.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.time_frame: Within 30 days from the day of the operation

secondary_outcome.description: Postoperative complications measured using Comprehensive complication index

secondary_outcome.time_frame: One and six months after the surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Patients' haemoglobin and iron parameter levels
secondary_outcome.description: Patients' haemoglobin and iron parameter levels

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within hospital stay, on average 7 - 14 days

secondary_outcome.measure: Use of IV iron after operation
secondary_outcome.description: Number of doses and median dose of IV iron

arm_group.description: IV-iron substitution: The intravenous iron formulation used in the study is ferric carboxymaltose and it will be administered two to four weeks before the surgery, aiming at four weeks. The dose of intravenous iron will be calculated according to the weight and haemoglobin level of the patients, however so that all the patients receive minimum 1000mg iv iron and the maximum dose is 20 mg/kg per day.
Placebo is NaCl 0.9% solution, which is administrated in the same way as the study drug

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with gastric cancer who will undergo a gastrectomy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients under 18 years old
- Patients not in full understanding
- Hemoglobin levels > 155 g/l for women and >167 g/l for men (upper reference limits for the laboratory of Helsinki University Hospital district) preoperatively.
- Transferrin saturation level >50%
- Emergency gastrectomy
- Palliative gastrectomy
- Acute bacterial infection
- Known hypersensitivity to the active substance, to ferric carboxymaltose or any of its excipients, or to other parental iron products
- Clinical evidence of iron overload or disturbances in the utilisation of iron
- Patients <35 kg
- Dialysis therapy for chronic renal failure
- Hemochromatosis
- Polycythemia vera
- Pregnancy
- Patients in need of direct blood transfusion ( Criteria for this are hemoglobin < 80 g/l or < 90 g/l if the patient is symptomatic or has a history of heart disease)
